Trustonic is a small OS running on the CPU providing a TEE, an isolated environment that runs in parallel with the operating system, guaranteeing code and data loaded inside to be protected.

See "com.trustonic.tuiservice"

AKA Accessory Framework
Quick device connect feature. Can be disabled via hidden setting (Settings -> Search 'App Enhancement Services' -> Quick device connect) if not wanted.
Allows you to search for nearby devices and connect to them without having to go through the Bluetooth or WiFi Direct settings' Ghosh! 32 permissions just for this?

label: System Messages
description:
Mobile Cloud Service? Message Controler System?.
My understanding is that this packages implements the communication logic of the Heytap services. It provides a MQTT client (and Firebase Cloud Manager for users outside of China) which frequently talks to heytapmobile.com. You can safely remove this package if you don't have a Heytap account.
Runs constantly in the background

label: com.mediatek
description:
Mediatek is a Taiwanese chipset manufacturer.
Can someone share the apk? This package name is really weird.
It is most likely a set of general APIs for accessing general mediatek functionalities.
Can someone share the apk?

label: ATMWifiMeta
description: wifi data logger you don't want

label: Call Recorder
description:
This is not the kind of feature expected from a Soc company.
If you remove this I guess you will not be able to record your calls from the stock dialer
Can someone share the apk and verify this?

label: EngineerMode
description:
Engineer mode you can access by dialing a secret code (*#*#3646633#*#* on some Xiaomi phones for instance)
It enables you to access the debug/logged data and some hidden firmware settings.

label: GPSLocationUpdate
description:
I wonder if it is really only a logging app.
Can someone try to remove it and use a GPS app to see if it still works?
Can someone share the apk? (from a Xiaomi/Huawei phone)

label: com.mediatek.im
description:
Mediatek's implementation of IMS (low-level implementation?)
IMS(Ip Multimedia Subsystem) is an open industry standard for voice and multimedia communications over packet-based IP networks (VoLTE/VoIP/Wifi calling).

label: com.mediatek.ims.pco
description:
Protocol Configuration Options service for IMS
IMS(IP Multimedia Subsystem) is an open industry standard for voice and multimedia communications over packet-based IP networks (VoLTE/VoIP/Wifi calling). This package enable automatic configuration pushed by your carrier.
warning: Maybe needed if you use IMS

label: LPPe Service
description:
LPPE = LTE Positioning Protocol enhancements/extensions (LTE = "4G")
Positioning and assistance protocol between E-SMLC (mobile location center) and UE (User Equipement = phone)
I don't know the app has the permission to read SMS

label: com.mediatek.mdmconfig
description:
Mobile Device Management (MDM) allows company’s IT department to reach inside your phone in the background, allowing them to ensure your device is secure, know where it is, and remotely erase your data if the phone is stolen.
It's a way to ensure employees stay productive and do not breach corporate policies
You should NEVER have a MDM tool on your personal phone. Never.
This package probably isn't a MDM tool on its own but you definitively don't need it on your phone.
Can someone share the apk?

label: MTKLogger
description:
Logs debug data. Has a lot of permissions and run in background all the time.
Don't keep useless apps: reduce the attack surface
Vulnerability found in this app in 2016

label: Mediatek Network Location Provider
description:
Provides periodic reports on the geographical location of the device. Each provider has a set of criteria under which it may be used. For example, some providers require GPS hardware and visibility to a number of satellites, while others require the use of the cellular radio, or access to a specific carrier's network, or to the internet.
I don't understand why this is needed; there already is one in 'com.google.android.gms'
I wonder if NLP can be replaced by https://github.com/microg/UnifiedNlp
I suggest testing if you get a better signal/battery performance with Mediatek NLP on or off.

label: Omacp
description:
omacp = OMA Client Provisioning. A protocol specified by the Open Mobile Alliance (OMA).
Configuration messages parser. Used for provisioning APN settings to devices via SMS.
In my case, it was automatic and I never needed configuration messages.
Maybe it's useful if carriers change their APN. But you can still change the config manually, it's not difficult.
Dunno why Mediatek handles this kind of things. Safe to remove. At worst, you'll need to manually config your APN.
OMACP can be abused.

label: DRM provider
description:
It actually Beep Science is MediaTek’s default DRM vendor
Probably required for some forms of DRM; disabling might break things like Netflix streaming, which relies on DRM to function.

label: com.mediatek.simprocessor
description: This controls and imports contacts saved on a SIM card. Not needed if you don't store your contacts on the SIM card

label: com.mediatek.wfo.impl
description:
According to olorin, it's a MediaTek’s default fingerprint app (and he removed it).
Can someone confirm what this package does?
Remember that any pre-installed apps you don't actually need just increase the surface attack.
Any app co-located on the device could modify a system property through an exported interface without proper authorization.
Vulnerability found in 2019

description:
App Spotlight
Makes you discover new apps from the Google Play store. The selection criteria is unknown.

label: com.pivotmobile.android.metrics
description:
Pivot Mobile is a popular game developer famously known for its Swimmy Turtle game.
Sub-downloaded by third-party apps; used for 'data consumption & ad' tracking.
Commonly found in Lenovo & Motorola devices.

label: com.playphone.gamestore
description:
Playphone Gamestore (https://www.playphone.com/)
"Helps" you discover the "best" Android games and connects you to a global gaming community. Sounds Amazing !

label: com.playphone.gamestore.loot
description:
Loot 
Premium service from playphone ?

label: myIM3
description:
App provided by Indosat Ooredoo, an Internet provider from Indonesia.
Enables Indosat users to manage prepaid and postpaid numbers and check their credit and payments, purchase data packs, calls, SMS...

label: Conference URI dialer
description: Conference call service for digital signal (SIP/VoIP).

label: com.qti.diagservices
description:
Starts process when plugged into a PC (with debugging on, haven't tried off) and then runs until stopped.
Can't find info on what it is. Probably has to do with diagnostics for Android debugging?
Noticed no ill effects from having it disabled for weeks.

label: com.qti.dpmserviceapp
description:
Data Power Manager for the radio.
Used to improve energy efficiency. Probably a bad idea to disable.

label: LTE Broadcast Manager
description: Runs on boot, but not in the background beyond that.

label: com.qti.qualcomm.datastatusnotification
description:
Sends you a message when you reach a specified data limit?
Contains a service, but I've never it run. But I've also never run out of data or used the Android data warning system.

label: Device Info
description: Displays device information. Can be found in Settings->About phone.

label: com.qti.service.colorservice
description:
Something to do with colors?
Contains a "ColorServiceApp" service, but I've never seen it run. Might be tied to some Display setting?
Probably safe to disable; noticed no changes, but I also doubt there's any benefit to disabling it.

label: QDCM-FF
description:
Qualcomm Display Color Management tool
Attempts to "make colors look vibrant and true to life". No idea if it actually does something useful or if it's only some garbage dynamic color tuning (they tend to destroy colors).
Contains a service, but I've never seen it run on my Oneplus 9. Could be tied to color "improvement" settings in Settings->Display (all of which are off for me).

label: Smart-Divert
description:
If enabled, diverts your calls to another number.
You can choose to divert all calls, divert on no reply or divert when the line is busy.
Where can you enable/disable this feature?

label: com.qualcomm.atfwd
description:
Used to send AT command messages from/to the modem
Attention commands commands are a collection of short-string commands developed in the early 1980s 
that were designed to be transmitted via phone lines and control modems. Different AT command strings can be merged together 
to tell a modem to dial, hang up, or change connection parameters. 
Smartphones include a basic modem component inside them, which allows the smartphone to connect to the Internet 
via its telephony function.
This can be abused. It's been known for many years that Android devices are vulnerable to attacks carried out via AT commands.

label: Content Adaptive Backlight Settings
description:
This app will try to adjust the image being displaye by changing the contrast/quality/image backlight depending on 
the content on the screen.
Downside to this is loss of dynamic range which results in some colors being washed out/clipped.
CABL != Auto brightness (which doesn't change the content of the screen, only the brightness)
NOTE: You may want to remove this. It does not work very well on many phones.

label: com.qualcomm.embms
description:
Runs on boot, but not in the background beyond that?
Adds support for eMBMS(evolved Multimedia Broadcast Multicast Service), also known as: LTE Broadcast
Enables carriers to send content using multicast/broadcast (same content to many users at the same time) instead of unicast(to a single user).
It's a more efficient use of network resources compared to users receiving the same content individually.
Probably safe to disable if you don't care about multi/broad-casts.

label: com.qualcomm.fastdormancy
description: Provide Fast Dormancy feature/setting in the dialer (reduce battery consumption and network utilization during periods of data inactivity)

label: LocationServices
description:
Runs in the background as part of the system. Runs even if disabled, so probably pointless to disable.
Periodically sends a unique software ID, location (lat, long, alt, and their uncertainty), nearby cellular towers and Wi-Fi hotspots and their signal strength to Qualcomm servers.

label: com.qualcomm.qcrilmsgtunnel
description:
Long-form name: Qualcomm Radio Interface Layer Message Tunnel.
Runs in the background, both as part of user apps and as part of the system? It's an active system process even when disabled, but disabling seems to remove the user-side part of the process.
Disabling yields no immediate consequences, but functionality may still be retained in the system process.
Acts as a bridge between Android framework services and the hardware? A tunnel between modem and Android framework?
The decompiled code shows nothing obvious. "sendOemRilRequest" seems like the only method name hinting at something.

label: FidoCryptoService
description:
Qualcomm FIDO implementation.
Fido is a set of open technical specifications for mechanisms of authenticating users to online services that do not depend on passwords.

label: com.qualcomm.qti.autoregistration
description:
Collects device activation data to remotely activate phone warranty.
In 2019 this package sent private data (IMEI, CELLID, CCID) in clear-text to zzhc.vnet.cn (chinese server). According to HMD (Nokia) it was a mistake.

label: com.qualcomm.qti.biometrics.fingerprint.service
description: Probably the background service for handling fingerprint authentication. Will likely break that if disabled.

label: CallEnhancement
description:
Supposed to enhance call quality (I'll let you test if it really does)
This can record your phone calls. A vulnerability was found in 2019, allowing unauthorized microphone audio recording by 3rd-party apps.

label: CallFeatureSetting
description:
Not mandatory according to some XDA users.
More info needed.

label: CneApp
description:
Connectivity Engine that runs in the background as part of the System.
Enables seamless hand-off between mobile data and Wi-Fi networks. Can also dynamically measure network performance to prioritize using the best one (I think that's part of "Intelligently select the best Wi-Fi" in settings).
Probably worth keeping on; I noticed connection reliability getting worse when I disabled it.

label: ConfDialer
description: LTE Conferencing Service.

label: com.qualcomm.qti.dynamicddsservice
description:
Dynamic DDS Service
DDS = Direct Digital Synthesizer. Supposedly useful for testing, communication and frequency sweep applications. Some apps may use this for local communication between devices? I'm guessing this is related to sending data through audio(a bunch of rapid beeps outside of the range of human hearing), which I believe Google Home used(still uses?) at one point as an option to connect to a Chromecast.

label: com.qualcomm.qti.ims
description:
IMS(Ip Multimedia Subsystem) is an open industry standard for voice and multimedia communications over packet-based IP networks (VoLTE/VoIP/Wifi calling).
Guessing this could be the low-level Qualcomm implementation or interface that allows apps to use the VoLTE/VoIP/Wi-Fi calling functionality in apps like the dialer/phone app.
Could allow seamless transfers of calls between 4G and Wi-Fi? I thought com.qualcomm.qti.cne did that content-agnostically, but maybe calls are different, or maybe the two packages use each other?

label: com.qualcomm.qti.lpa
description:
lpa = Local Profile Assistants
Runs on boot, but not in the background beyond that.
Code has a lot of references to UIM(User Identity Module, which is SIM-related)
Only useful if you use an eSIM? (electronic SIM)
Allows users to choose and change their subscription data when switching between network operators/carriers.

label: Network operators
description: A hidden settings menu that lets you select network modes like GSM only, WCDMA only, LTE only etc, toggle VoLTE On/Off...

label: com.qualcomm.qti.optinoverlay
description: Overlay for opting into something? Probably safe to disable?

label: Perfdump
description:
Performance dump (logging)
Enable a more accurate overview of the running services (and maybe how much power/RAM they take?)

label: Performance Mode
description:
Runs on boot. Probably related to CPU/SoC performance profiles.
Oneplus 10 Pro has an option called "High performance mode" in Settings->Battery->Advanced, which has the description:
"The system always operates in a high performance mode, but it will increase power consumption."
I'm guessing that option triggers this package. This is probably a feature on many Qualcomm chips, but I don't think all OEMs expose it in the settings.

label: PowerOffAlarm
description:
Probably what enables alarms to start the device from an off state.
Runs on boot and when you open a clock app.

label: QColor
description:
Something to do with colors?
Contains no services and I've never seen it run as a process. Only has one permission: CONTROL_DISPLAY_COLOR_TRANSFORMS
Probably safe to disable; noticed no changes, but I also doubt there's any benefit to disabling it.

label: QDMA
description:
QDMA = Quadrature-Division Multiple Access
It's a radio protocol combining CDMA and QPSK.
QDMA is used for local area networks, usually wireless short-range such as WiMax.

label: QMMI
description: QMMI is a test app made by Qualcomm. It is used by service center to test the working of the various device components.

label: com.qualcomm.qti.qms.service.connectionsecurity
description:
Telemetry service
qms = quality management service
Background-Connection to tls.telemetry.swe.quicinc.com (Host/Domain belongs to Qualcomm)

label: Qualcomm Mobile Security
description: Telemetry service. Obviously phones to Qualcomm.

label: com.qualcomm.qti.qtisystemservice
description:
Seems to only log stuff related to telephony?
A user removed this without noticing any issues.

label: com.qualcomm.qti.rcsimsbootstraputil
description:
RCS Service
RCS = Rich Communication Services.
RCS is a communication protocol between mobile telephone carriers and between phone and carrier, aiming at replacing SMS.
Uses IP protocol so it needs an internet connection.
It's a hot mess right now. It aims at being universal but only exists in Samsung Messages and Google Messages, because Google hasn't released a public API yet, so 3rd-party apps can't support it.
In a lot of countries messages go through Google's Jibe servers.
Can anybody check if this is needed for VolTE/VoWifi?

label: com.qualcomm.qti.remoteSimlockAuth
description: Authentication for locking/unlocking eSIM remotely?

label: Roaming Settings
description: Hidden settings menu for tweaking roaming settings? How exactly do you access this menu?

label: SecCamService
description:
Stands for Secure Camera Service?
Supposedly acts as a bridge between camera hardware and SoC. Seems like this package is what a Qualcomm SoC uses to access the camera hardware.
Will probably break camera functionality if disabled.

label: com.qualcomm.qti.simsettings
description: Related to SIM settings? Exact nature is unclear.

label: com.qualcomm.qti.smq
description:
QTR (Qualcomm Technology Reporting)
Runs on boot.
Seems like a telemetry package, supposedly sending hardware & software type, configuration and performance data.
Contains a "QtiFeedbackActivity" called "Hardware Feedback". When that hidden activity is launched through Activity Launcher you get a screen showing just a checkbox and this text:
"Collecting hardware and software type, configuration, and performance data helps Qualcomm improve next generation device battery life, security, and performance. Untick to disable."
Unticking isn't remembered; it's ticked again next time you enter. There's also a "Learn More" link that leads to: http://reporting.qti.qualcomm.com/learnmore_en.html which doesn't load for me.

label: com.qualcomm.qti.telephony.vodafonepack
description:
Related to Vodafone Prepaid Recharge Plan
If you're not a Vodafone client but still has this package on your phone you can delete it.
For Vodafone client, I don't know what this package does.

label: uceShimService
description:
UCE shim service
UCE = User Capability Exchange. A shim is basically a compatibility layer for an API, that makes sure anything that uses the API does so correctly.
Used for RCS. Provides a discovery service for users to see the capabilities of other users.
UCE is based on SIP PUBLISH and SIP SUBSCRIBE/NOTIFY.
Devices PUBLISH their capabilities to a presence server, when another device wants to find out what the other party supports, the device sends a SUBSCRIBE to the presence server which then returns a NOTIFY of what the other party supports.

label: uceShimService
description:
UCE shim service
UCE = User Capability Exchange. A shim is basically a compatibility layer for an API, that makes sure anything that uses the API does so correctly.
Used for RCS. Provides a discovery service for users to see the capabilities of other users.
UCE is based on SIP PUBLISH and SIP SUBSCRIBE/NOTIFY.
Devices PUBLISH their capabilities to a presence server, when another device wants to find out what the other party supports, the device sends a SUBSCRIBE to the presence server which then returns a NOTIFY of what the other party supports.

label: Trusted User Interface
description:
A security layer by Trustonic.
Allows a "Trusted App" to interact directly with the user, completely isolated from the device OS.
It's closed source and normal devs can't use it for their apps.
Mainly used by OEM apps like Samsung Pay and for DRM.
Google implemented their own TUI in Android Pie: https://android-developers.googleblog.com/search/label/Trusted%20User%20Interface
https://www.trustonic.com/news/blog/benefits-trusted-user-interface/
Disabling will break "Trusted Apps".

label: SmartcardService

The SmartCard API is a reference implementation of the SIMalliance Open Mobile API specification that enables Android applications to communicate with Secure Elements, (SIM card, embedded Secure Elements, Mobile Security Card or others)
Safe to remove if you think you don't need this

label: org.simalliance.openmobileapi.uicc2terminal
description:
Open Mobile API ("interface") to access UICC secure elements 
UICC stands for Universal Integrated Circuit Card. 
It is the physical and logical platform for the USIM and may contain additional USIMs and other applications.
(U)SIM is an application on the UICC.
Note2: The term SIM is widely used in the industry and especially with consumers to mean both SIMs and UICCs.

label: CACertApp
description:
Occasionally runs in the background.
Handles CACert certificates?
CACert is a community-driven CA that issues certificates to the public at large for free. CA = Certificate Authority, an entity that certifies the ownership of a public key that can be used for secure communications.
warning: Probably a bad idea to disable; could mess with device security.
